{"step_by_step_thinking": "Unattached gingiva refers to the part of the gums that is not directly attached to the teeth. This includes the interdental gingiva, which is the gum tissue found in the space between two teeth. However, it is not below the mucogingival fold, which is the line where the attached gingiva meets the unattached or alveolar mucosa. It can be separated by a probe, which is used to measure the depth of gum pockets. Lastly, it is not the marginal gingiva, which is the part of the gum that is directly adjacent to the teeth and is firmly attached.", "answer_choice": "A"}
